title: Long-Term Investment
descriptions:
Title: Long-Term Investment: A Multifaceted Study of Determinants and Consequences

Abstract:

The Long-Term Investment project proposes a comprehensive study of the determinants and consequences of long-term investment in the 21st-century firm. By comparing the characteristics of 20th-century firms, which focused on cost efficiency and tangible assets, with those of 21st-century firms, which compete on product quality and rely on intangible assets such as brand strength, innovation, and corporate culture, this project aims to shed light on the complexities of long-term investment. The project is divided into three linked components: Financial Markets, Incentives, and Effects of Investment.

The Financial Markets component will investigate the incorporation of information about future investment opportunities into stock prices, with a focus on determining the efficiency of information channels. The Incentives component will analyze the impact of managerial pay and pay sensitivity to performance on long-term investment decisions, with a focus on optimal incentive horizons. The Effects of Investment component will explore the link between corporate social responsibility and firm value, with a view to demonstrating the benefits of long-term investment.

This project seeks to address the challenges posed by managerial pressure to maximize short-term earnings and the difficulties in demonstrating the benefits of long-term investment. By combining insights from finance, management, and economics, this project aims to provide a nuanced understanding of the determinants and consequences of long-term investment and to inform policy and practice in this area.
